questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right-sided blurry vision and eye pain for the past 4 days. She has a 6-day history of low-grade fever, headache, and malaise. One year ago, she was diagnosed with Crohn disease. Her only medication is prednisone. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 112/75 mm Hg. The right eyelid is erythematous and tender; there are multiple vesicles over the right forehead and the tip of the nose. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the left eye and 20/80 in the right eye. Extraocular movements are normal. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and reduced corneal sensitivity. Fluorescein staining shows a corneal lesion with a tree-like pattern. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas keratitis is the most common form of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users, and it manifests with rapid progression of painful blurry vision, purulent eye discharge, and round corneal ulceration. This patient does not use contact lenses and presents with slow-onset blurry vision and eye pain, low-grade fever, vesicular skin lesions, and a dendritic corneal lesion without purulent discharge, making pseudomonal keratitis an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

B) INCORRECT:

Anterior uveitis can be caused by infectious agents (e.g., HSV, CMV) or autoimmune processes. It manifests with reduced vision, eye pain, and conjunctival erythema, and Crohn disease is a risk factor. However, slit lamp examination typically shows inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber and anterior uveitis does not manifest with dendritic corneal lesions, fever, or vesicular skin lesions.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp examination of the anterior part of the eye

Iris details are blurred. This indicates inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. Keratic precipitates, originating from inflammatory material, are present on the endothelium of the cornea.

These are typical signs of anterior uveitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is characterized by malaise, fever and eyelid erythema and swelling. However, this condition does not manifest with facial vesicles or dendritic corneal lesions. Moreover, this patient is lacking other typical symptoms of orbital cellulitis, such as exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia, and pain with eye movements.
Image Description:

Orbital region of a 45-year-old patient with headache, yellowish rhinorrhea, and diplopia

Swelling and erythema of the left eyelid are present.

In light of the patient's other symptoms, especially diplopia, orbital cellulitis is the most probable diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Herpes zoster keratitis is a manifestation of herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which typically starts with a prodrome (fever, headache, malaise) followed by unilateral painful impaired vision with reduced corneal sensation and vesicular skin lesions in the area innervated by the ophthalmic nerve (forehead, bridge, and tip of the nose). Fluorescein staining typically first shows punctate lesions on the corneal surface that evolve into pseudodendritic lesions after 4–6 days, as seen here. Treatment consists of oral acyclovir, valacyclovir, or famciclovir.

See “Keratitis overview” table.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eye

Superficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).

In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

E) INCORRECT:

Angle-closure glaucoma can manifest with unilateral eye pain, blurred vision, conjunctival injection, and a cloudy cornea. However, symptoms typically appear very suddenly and include headaches, nausea and vomiting, a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil, and a hard eyeball on palpation. Angle-closure glaucoma does not cause facial vesicles or dendritic lesions on the corneal surface.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

F) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) can manifest with unilateral ocular irritation, eye pain with reduced corneal sensation, skin vesicles, and dendritic ulceration on fluorescein staining. However, vesicles in HSV keratitis mainly occur at the ipsilateral eyelid and would not occur throughout the dermatome of the ophthalmic nerve (forehead, bridge, and tip of the nose).
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.
questions.hint: Immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., with prednisone) increases the risk of reactivation of a dormant virus.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of pain and watery discharge in her left eye. She also has blurry vision and noticed that she is more sensitive to light. Her right eye is asymptomatic. She had an episode of shingles 7 years ago. She was diagnosed with HIV 5 years ago. She admits that she takes her medication inconsistently. She wears contact lenses. Current medications include abacavir, lamivudine, efavirenz, and a nutritional supplement. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival injection of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/80 in the left eye. Extraocular movements are normal. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. A photograph of the left eye after fluorescein administration is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurotrophic keratopathy (NK) is caused by nerve damage due to trauma, surgery, LASIK, or herpes infection. Given that this patient has a herpes infection, she is at risk of developing NK. However, NK manifests with decreased visual acuity, chronic dry eye, and the absence of eye pain. On slit lamp examination, spots on the corneal epithelium (early stage) or a circular/oval non-healing corneal ulcer (late stage) are visible. This patient presents with an acute 3-day history of eye pain, watery discharge, and a dendritic ulcer on examination, making NK an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas keratitis is more common in contact lens wearers and immunosuppressed patients and typically manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity. Although this patient presents similarly, slit lamp examination would show a central, white corneal ulcer, often accompanied by a hypopyon, rather than a dendritic ulcer.
Image Description:

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster keratitis can occur in immunocompromised individuals and manifests with a dendritic ulcer on slit lamp examination, like in this patient. However, herpes zoster keratitis typically manifests with a prodrome (fever, malaise) and vesicular eruptions on the ipsilateral forehead, eyelids, and nose. As this patient has no prodromal symptoms or skin findings, another diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eye

Superficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).

In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

D) INCORRECT:

Fusarium keratitis is a type of fungal keratitis that is more common in contact lens users and in immunocompromised individuals. This condition can also manifest with ocular pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. However, on slit lamp examination, fungal keratitis typically presents as an ulcer with a filamentous edge and an accompanying hypopyon.

E) CORRECT:

Acute onset of unilateral eye pain and redness, watery discharge, photophobia, and blurry vision indicates HSV keratitis. Dendritic corneal ulcers that stain with fluorescein are characteristic of this condition. HSV is widespread and primary ocular infection can follow inoculation via direct contact. However, most ocular infections are caused by viral reactivation and replication, which can occur in immunocompromised individuals like this patient with AIDS. Topical antiviral therapy with trifluridine or ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for HSV keratitis.

See “Keratitis overview” table.

F) INCORRECT:

Although acanthamoeba keratitis is more common in contact lens users and also manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity, slit lamp examination would show a ring-shaped corneal ulcer rather than a dendritic ulcer. In addition, acanthamoeba keratitis typically develops slowly over the course of weeks, despite antibiotic treatment, and the onset of symptoms is not as rapid as in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has AIDS (T-lymphocytes < 200/mm3) and acquired an opportunistic eye infection. The photograph shows a corneal lesion that resembles the branches of a tree.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain, excessive tearing, and blurry vision of his right eye. He first noticed his symptoms last evening while he was watching a movie at a theater. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has atopic dermatitis treated with topical hydrocortisone. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and 20/40 in the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and an edematous cornea with a whitish exudate at the bottom of the anterior chamber. Fluorescein staining shows a round corneal infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are used to treat allergic conjunctivitis. This patient's atopic dermatitis increases his risk of developing allergic conjunctivitis. While allergic conjunctivitis also manifests with redness and excessive tearing, it is more common in young adults and most often manifests with itching and bilateral eye involvement. Furthermore, allergic conjunctivitis does not cause a corneal infiltrate or a hypopyon.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is indicated in the treatment of herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) if topical treatment cannot be administered by the patient or has not been effective. While HSV keratitis can manifest with unilateral eye redness and pain, there are no findings on this patient's slit lamp examination suggestive of this condition (e.g., dendritic or geographic corneal lesion or vesicles). The presence of a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon indicates bacterial keratitis, for which oral acyclovir is not indicated.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

C) CORRECT:

Empiric topical broad-spectrum antibiotics are the pharmacotherapy of choice in the management of bacterial keratitis. Since this condition can quickly lead to irreversible vision loss and corneal destruction, it is considered an ophthalmic emergency and treatment should be initiated immediately. Following identification of the responsible pathogen and about 2 days of antibiotic therapy, the patient may be additionally started on corticosteroid therapy in order to reduce excessive inflammation. Contact lens use is an important risk factor for bacterial keratitis and is most commonly associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

See “Keratitis overview” table.
Image Description:

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical timolol and pilocarpine are indicated for the treatment of angle-closure glaucoma, which manifests with a sudden, unilateral onset of severe pain, ocular inflammation, and blurry vision. Darkness (e.g., in a movie theater) can trigger this condition since the pupil dilates and causes obstruction of the trabecular meshwork outflow tract. However, further signs and symptoms such as headache, nausea and vomiting, a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil, and a hard eyeball on palpation are expected in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical prednisolone may be used to treat anterior uveitis, which can manifest with unilateral progressive eye pain, eye redness, decreased visual acuity, increased lacrimation, and hypopyon. However, pupils are typically constricted or irregular due to posterior synechiae formation. Additionally, a round corneal infiltrate is suggestive of bacterial keratitis. Topical prednisolone may be used to treat severe bacterial keratitis following identification of the pathogen and ∼ 2 days of appropriate therapy but is not the initial treatment of choice.
Image Description:

Left eye

Massive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).

The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.

Dashed line: surrounds cornea

F) INCORRECT:

Topical ganciclovir is indicated to treat herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis), which typically also manifests with unilateral eye redness and pain. However, this patient has no typical findings of HSV keratitis on slit lamp examination (e.g., dendritic or geographic corneal lesion and vesicles). The presence of a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon indicates bacterial keratitis, for which topical ganciclovir is not indicated.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.
questions.hint: This contact lens wearing patient presents with unilateral progressive eye pain, eye redness, impaired vision, and excessive tearing. Together with a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon, this is highly suggestive of severe bacterial keratitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He has difficulties opening the eye because of pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He works as a kindergarten teacher. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mm Hg. Examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus keratitis is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among individuals who do not use contact lenses, and it can manifest with a painful decline in vision, conjunctival injection, hypopyon, and corneal infiltrates. However, this patient's history of contact lens use and the rapid progression of symptoms make another causative organism more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa easily adheres to contact lenses and is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among contact lens users. Risk factors include wearing contact lenses for an extended period of time and poor contact lens hygiene. Pseudomonas keratitis typically manifests with a rapid progression of symptoms, such as a decline in vision, eye pain and difficulties opening the affected eye, redness, photophobia, and foreign body sensation. If left untreated, pseudomonas keratitis can lead to corneal perforation within 2–5 days. Therefore, urgent treatment with topical broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., cefazolin with tobramycin or gentamicin) should be initiated. In addition, patients should be educated about contact lens hygiene (washing hands before touching the lenses, using fresh lens solution, not using saliva to wet lenses).

C) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with an acute onset of monocular pain, blurred vision, conjunctival injection, and a cloudy cornea. However, it typically also leads to a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil and a hard eyeball on palpation. Furthermore, glaucoma does not cause a hypopyon or a corneal infiltrate.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) can manifest with ocular pain and blurry vision. However, HSV keratitis typically progresses over 1–3 days; unlike this patient's rapid development in one day. In addition, slit lamp examination in HSV keratitis would show the pathognomonic dendritic ulcer rather than the circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography with fluorescein stain and cobalt blue light filter

Dendritic lesions of the cornea appear green under cobalt blue illumination after fluorescein stain.

These lesions are characteristic of keratitis caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).

E) INCORRECT:

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is a highly contagious adenoviral infection that is spread commonly among groups of people (e.g., in kindergartens, nursing homes). EKC usually manifests with bilateral ocular pain, foreign body sensation, blurring of vision, conjunctival injection, and edema of the eyelids and conjunctiva. While corneal involvement with subepithelial infiltrates may develop after a few days, EKC affects both eyes and does not manifest with rapid onset of a circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon.

F) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster keratitis typically manifests with a prodrome of fever and malaise, which is followed by eye pain, impaired vision, and eruption of vesicles in the dermatomal distribution of the ophthalmic nerve (e.g., ipsilateral forehead, tip of nose). Corneal involvement is seen as a dendritic ulcer (branching pattern on the corneal epithelium) on slit lamp examination. This patient's presentation with rapid progression of ocular symptoms, the presence of a circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon, with the absence of prodromal symptoms or skin findings is inconsistent with herpes zoster keratitis.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eye

Superficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).

In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

G) INCORRECT:

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a subtype of allergic conjunctivitis that manifests with seasonal itching and watering of both eyes and typically occurs in children. The pathognomonic sign of VKC is the presence of giant papillae on the tarsal conjunctiva (cobblestone appearance). A corneal erosion that resembles the shape of a shield (shield ulcer) may occur after several days of symptoms. Although this patient's history of asthma is a risk factor for the development of VKC, the acute onset and rapid progression of symptoms in a single eye, and absence of itching or giant papillae, make it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
Image Description:

Ectropionized upper right eyelid of a young boy

Cobblestone-like lesions, called “giant papillae” (green outline), are visible on the tarsal conjunctive of the upper eyelid.

This finding is consistent with vernal keratoconjunctivitis, a severe form of allergic inflammation in the eye. It may lead to further complications, including corneal ulcer.
questions.hint: The photograph shows conjunctival injection, accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber (hypopyon), and a round corneal infiltrate suggestive of an ulcer. In a patient using contact lenses, these findings indicate infective keratitis caused by a specific pathogen.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for 2 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. A culture of the ocular discharge is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Gram-negative spiral bacteria visible on dark-field microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhea (gram-negative, non-maltose fermenting diplococci) is typically associated with neonatal conjunctivitis. It can cause keratitis but it is not the most common cause of keratitis in contact lens users. Moreover, N. gonorrhea has shown resistance to ciprofloxacin. If N. gonorrhea is suspected, treatment with a third-generation cephalosporin is recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus (gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci) is a relatively common cause of keratitis and ciprofloxacin would cover S. aureus but S. aureus is not the most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users.

C) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum (a gram-negative spiral bacteria visible on dark-field microscopy) causes syphilitic keratitis, a complication of secondary syphilis. However, syphilitic keratitis has a subacute or chronic course, and the patient does not have any features suggestive of secondary syphilis (e.g., fever, lethargy, rash, condylomata lata). Moreover, ciprofloxacin is not an effective treatment for syphilis; penicillin is the antibiotic of choice when Treponema pallidum is suspected.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes (gram-positive, bacitracin-sensitive cocci) causes keratitis only in rare cases. This bacterium typically causes scarlet fever, acute otitis media, and soft tissue infections (e.g., erysipelas, cellulitis, impetigo). Additionally, ciprofloxacin is not the ideal treatment because S. pyogenes shows mild resistance to fluoroquinolones. Typically, beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin, amoxicillin, second-generation cephalosporins) are the first-line treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative, lactose-fermenting bacilli such as Escherichia coli and Klebsiella pneumoniae can cause keratitis, and ciprofloxacin can be used to treat infections with these organisms. However, these pathogens are not the most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users. In this case, the most likely pathogen is a lactose non-fermenter.

F) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive, non-lactose fermenting encapsulated bacilli. Prompt antibiotic therapy is required to prevent complications such as corneal scarring and loss of vision. Ciprofloxacin, aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin), and polymyxin B are effective against P. aeruginosa and are used topically to treat keratitis. Other antibiotics that are effective against P. aeruginosa include ceftazidime, cefepime, piperacillin-tazobactam, and ticarcillin, but these antibiotics are typically used systemically.

G) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (gram-positive, optochin-sensitive diplococci) can cause keratitis but it is not the leading cause of keratitis in contact lens users. S. pneumoniae is the most likely causal organism in the following clinical scenarios: adult community-acquired pneumonia, childhood otitis media, and bacterial meningitis in anyone older than 6 months. Moreover, Streptococcus pneumoniae is increasingly fluoroquinolone resistant; beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin, amoxicillin, 2nd generation cephalosporins) are therefore preferred for S. pneumoniae.
questions.hint: The patient's severe eye pain, corneal ulcer, and purulent discharge are consistent with bacterial keratitis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users (> 60% of cases)

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of right-sided eye and forehead pain, blurry vision, and a rash in the V1 dermatome that does not cross the midline. Fluorescein dye is applied to the patient's right cornea, and the eye is examined under cobalt-blue light.
Which one of the following findings is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms suggest herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO), which refers to ocular involvement of the varicella-zoster virus, most commonly in a V1 distribution (and less commonly in a V2 distribution). HZO can lead to many ocular complications, including eyelid ulcers, corneal damage, glaucoma, retinal necrosis, optic neuritis, and nerve palsies. The presence of a rash along the side of the nose (Hutchinson sign) is a predictor of ocular involvement.

Pseudodendrites are a common corneal finding in HZO and are a form of keratitis. When the cornea is stained with fluorescein dye and observed under cobalt-blue light, pseudodendrites have a branching appearance and appear yellow. They typically appear “stuck on” without any associated ulceration. Although corneal ulcers can be seen in viral infections, the pseudodendrite pattern is typical in herpes zoster and helps confirm the etiology. Typical dendrites with ulceration are seen in herpes simplex ophthalmicus.

Treatment of HZO depends on the type of ocular involvement and can include oral, topical, and intravitreal antivirals, topical glucocorticoids, and cycloplegics with dilating drops. All patients with V1 or V2 distributions of HZO should receive a prompt ocular examination.

Key learning point: Pseudodendrites on the cornea are indicative of herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

B) INCORRECT:

Although corneal ulcers can be seen in viral infections, the pseudodendrite pattern is typical in herpes zoster and helps confirm the etiology. Typical dendrites with ulceration are seen in herpes simplex ophthalmicus.

C) INCORRECT:

Episcleritis (inflammation of the episclera) is associated with injection, discomfort, and photophobia. The cornea is not involved, and there are no orbital skin changes.

D) INCORRECT:

A hypopyon (which appears as a white, semicircular, inferior collection behind the cornea) is usually seen in severe ocular infection, such as an advanced corneal ulcer and endophthalmitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Keratoconus is a corneal disease characterized by paracentral corneal thinning and protrusion.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-day history of progressive pain, excessive tearing, and decreased visual acuity of his right eye. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. The right eye shows conjunctival injection and an edematous cornea with a whitish exudate at the bottom of the anterior chamber. Fluorescein staining shows a round corneal infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical ketorolac and artificial tears are used to treat allergic conjunctivitis. While allergic conjunctivitis also manifests with redness and excessive tearing, it is more common in young adults and most often manifests with itching and bilateral eye involvement. Furthermore, allergic conjunctivitis does not cause a corneal infiltrate or a hypopyon.
Image Description:

Right eye of an older adult

Conjunctival injection, massive chemosis, and tearing are visible. The eyelids appear edematous.

This is the classical appearance of allergic conjunctivitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is indicated in the treatment of herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) if topical treatment cannot be administered by the patient or has not been effective. While HSV keratitis can manifest with unilateral eye redness and pain, there are no findings on this patient's slit lamp examination suggestive of this condition (e.g., dendritic or geographic corneal lesion or vesicles). The presence of a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon indicates bacterial keratitis, for which oral acyclovir is not indicated.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography of the cornea (fluorescein stain)

Dendritic lesions (red overlay) are visible on the cornea.

This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex keratitis.

C) CORRECT:

Empiric topical broad-spectrum antibiotics are the pharmacotherapy of choice in the management of bacterial keratitis. Since this condition can quickly lead to irreversible vision loss and corneal destruction, it is considered an ophthalmic emergency and treatment should be initiated immediately. Following identification of the responsible pathogen and about 2 days of antibiotic therapy, the patient may be additionally started on corticosteroid therapy in order to reduce excessive inflammation. Contact lens use is an important risk factor for bacterial keratitis and is most commonly associated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

See “Keratitis overview” table.
Image Description:

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical timolol and pilocarpine are indicated for the treatment of angle-closure glaucoma, which manifests with a sudden, unilateral onset of severe pain, ocular inflammation, and blurry vision. However, further signs and symptoms such as headache, nausea and vomiting, a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil, and a hard eyeball on palpation are expected in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical prednisolone may be used to treat anterior uveitis, which can manifest with unilateral progressive eye pain, eye redness, decreased visual acuity, increased lacrimation, and hypopyon. However, photophobia and either keratic precipitates on the corneal endothelium or a clear cornea are expected on examination. A round corneal infiltrate is suggestive of bacterial keratitis. Topical prednisolone may be used to treat severe bacterial keratitis following identification of the pathogen and ∼ 2 days of appropriate therapy but is not the initial treatment of choice.
Image Description:

Left eye

Massive mixed injections are present. Iris details appear blurred, which may result from corneal edema or inflammatory infiltration of the anterior chamber. The pupil (green overlay) is not completely round, which may be due to posterior synechiae. White material can be seen in the inferior region of the anterior chamber (hypopyon, blue overlay).

The massive inflammatory process seen here could be due to, e.g., postoperative endophthalmitis or very severe uveitis.

Dashed line: surrounds cornea
questions.hint: This contact lens wearing patient presents with unilateral progressive eye pain, eye redness, impaired vision, and excessive tearing. Together with a round corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon, this is highly suggestive of severe bacterial keratitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-day history of pain and watery discharge in her left eye. She also has blurry vision and noticed that she is more sensitive to light. She was diagnosed with HIV 5 years ago and takes her medication inconsistently. She wears contact lenses. Examination shows conjunctival injection of the left eye. Visual acuity is 20/80 in the left eye. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90/mm3. A photograph of the left eye after fluorescein administration is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas keratitis is more common in contact lens wearers and immunosuppressed patients and typically manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity. Although this patient presents similarly, slit lamp examination would show a central, white corneal ulcer, often accompanied by a hypopyon, rather than a dendritic ulcer.
Image Description:

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection; examples indicated by arrowheads). A dense corneal infiltration (white opacification; green overlay) is visible at the center of the cornea. The peripheral cornea shows slight opacification indicating corneal decompensation (blurred details of the iris). An accumulation of white-yellow exudate (hypopyon; blue overlay) consisting of inflammatory cells and/or bacteria/fungi within the anterior chamber can be seen completely covering the inferior aspect of the iris.

These findings are consistent with infective keratitis, associated here with contact lens use.

B) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster keratitis can occur in immunocompromised individuals and manifests with a dendritic ulcer on slit lamp examination, like in this patient. However, herpes zoster keratitis typically manifests with a prodrome (fever, malaise) and vesicular eruptions on the ipsilateral forehead, eyelids, and nose. As this patient has no prodromal symptoms or skin findings, another diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography, blue-light filter with fluorescein staining of a left eye

Superficial patchy erosions, marked by the fluorescein staining, are visible in a geographic pattern on the surface of the cornea (examples indicated by red overlay).

In combination with the cutaneous red lesions in the supraorbital region, the findings are typical for keratitis caused by herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

C) INCORRECT:

Fusarium keratitis is a type of fungal keratitis that is more common in contact lens users and in immunocompromised individuals. This condition can also manifest with ocular pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. However, on slit lamp examination, fungal keratitis typically presents as an ulcer with a filamentous edge and an accompanying hypopyon.

D) CORRECT:

Acute onset of unilateral eye pain and redness, watery discharge, photophobia, and blurry vision indicates HSV keratitis. Dendritic corneal ulcers that stain with fluorescein are characteristic of this condition. HSV is widespread and primary ocular infection can follow inoculation via direct contact. However, most ocular infections are caused by viral reactivation and replication, which can occur in immunocompromised individuals like this patient with AIDS. Topical antiviral therapy with trifluridine or ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for HSV keratitis.

See “Keratitis overview” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Although acanthamoeba keratitis is more common in contact lens users and also manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity, slit lamp examination would show a ring-shaped corneal ulcer rather than a dendritic ulcer. In addition, acanthamoeba keratitis typically develops slowly over the course of weeks, despite antibiotic treatment, and the onset of symptoms is not as rapid as in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has AIDS (T-lymphocytes < 200/mm3) and acquired an opportunistic eye infection. The photograph shows a corneal lesion that resembles the branches of a tree.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus keratitis is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among individuals who do not use contact lenses, and it can manifest with a painful decline in vision, conjunctival injection, hypopyon, and corneal infiltrates. However, this patient's history of contact lens use and the rapid progression of symptoms make another causative organism more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa easily adheres to contact lenses and is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among contact lens users. Risk factors include wearing contact lenses for an extended period of time and poor contact lens hygiene. Pseudomonas keratitis typically manifests with a rapid progression of symptoms, such as a decline in vision, eye pain, redness, photophobia, and foreign body sensation. If left untreated, pseudomonas keratitis can lead to corneal perforation within 2–5 days. Therefore, urgent treatment with topical broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., cefazolin with tobramycin or gentamicin) should be initiated. In addition, patients should be educated about contact lens hygiene (washing hands before touching the lenses, using fresh lens solution, not using saliva to wet lenses).

Key learning point: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of rapidly progressive bacterial keratitis in contact lens users, presenting with pain, vision loss, corneal infiltrate, and hypopyon.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with an acute onset of monocular pain, blurred vision, conjunctival injection, and a cloudy cornea. However, it typically also leads to a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil and a hard eyeball on palpation. Furthermore, glaucoma does not cause a hypopyon or a corneal infiltrate.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photograph of anterior eye segment

Prominent blood vessels are visible on the sclera and conjunctiva (mixed injection). The pupil is medium wide and its shape is slightly irregular. Iris details appear blurred due to corneal endothelial decompensation, leading to corneal edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) can manifest with ocular pain and blurry vision. However, HSV keratitis typically progresses over 1–3 days; unlike this patient's rapid development in one day. In addition, slit lamp examination in HSV keratitis would show the pathognomonic dendritic ulcer rather than the circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Slit-lamp photography with fluorescein stain and cobalt blue light filter

Dendritic lesions of the cornea appear green under cobalt blue illumination after fluorescein stain.

These lesions are characteristic of keratitis caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV).

E) INCORRECT:

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is a highly contagious adenoviral infection that is spread commonly among groups of people. EKC usually manifests with bilateral ocular pain, foreign body sensation, blurring of vision, conjunctival injection, and edema of the eyelids and conjunctiva. While corneal involvement with subepithelial infiltrates may develop after a few days, EKC affects both eyes and does not manifest with rapid onset of a circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon.
questions.hint: The photograph shows conjunctival injection, accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber (hypopyon), and a round corneal infiltrate suggestive of an ulcer. In a patient using contact lenses, these findings indicate infective keratitis caused by a specific pathogen.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of pain and watery discharge in her left eye. She also reports blurry vision and increased sensitivity to light. She was diagnosed with HIV 5 years ago and reports inconsistent adherence to her medication. She wears contact lenses. On examination, there is conjunctival injection of the left eye. Visual acuity in the left eye is 20/80. Her CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 90 cells/μL (500–2000). A photograph of the left eye after fluorescein administration is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute onset of unilateral eye pain and redness, watery discharge, photophobia, and blurry vision indicates HSV keratitis. Dendritic corneal ulcers that stain with fluorescein are characteristic of this condition. HSV is widespread and primary ocular infection can follow inoculation via direct contact. However, most ocular infections are caused by viral reactivation and replication, which can occur in immunocompromised individuals like this patient with AIDS. Topical antiviral therapy with trifluridine or ganciclovir is the treatment of choice for HSV keratitis.

See “Keratitis overview” table.

Key learning point: Herpes simplex keratitis presents with acute unilateral eye pain, watery discharge, photophobia, and a characteristic dendritic corneal ulcer that stains with fluorescein.

B) INCORRECT:

Although acanthamoeba keratitis is more common in contact lens users and also manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity, slit lamp examination would show a ring-shaped corneal ulcer rather than a dendritic ulcer. In addition, acanthamoeba keratitis typically develops slowly over the course of weeks, despite antibiotic treatment, and the onset of symptoms is not as rapid as in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Fusarium keratitis is a type of fungal keratitis that is more common in contact lens users and in immunocompromised individuals. This condition can also manifest with ocular pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. However, on slit lamp examination, fungal keratitis typically presents as an ulcer with a filamentous edge and an accompanying hypopyon.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas keratitis is more common in contact lens wearers and immunosuppressed patients and typically manifests with ocular pain, photophobia, epiphora, and decreased visual acuity. Although this patient presents similarly, slit lamp examination would show a central, white corneal ulcer, often accompanied by a hypopyon, rather than a dendritic ulcer.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster keratitis can occur in immunocompromised individuals and manifests with a dendritic ulcer on slit lamp examination, like in this patient. However, herpes zoster keratitis typically manifests with a prodrome (fever, malaise) and vesicular eruptions on the ipsilateral forehead, eyelids, and nose. As this patient has no prodromal symptoms or skin findings, another diagnosis is more likely.
questions.hint: This patient has AIDS (T-lymphocytes < 200/μL) and acquired an opportunistic eye infection. The photograph shows a corneal lesion that resembles the branches of a tree.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. A photograph of the right eye is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute angle-closure glaucoma manifests with an acute onset of monocular pain, blurred vision, conjunctival injection, and a cloudy cornea. However, it typically also leads to a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil and a hard eyeball on palpation. Furthermore, glaucoma does not cause a hypopyon or a corneal infiltrate.

B) INCORRECT:

Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (EKC) is a highly contagious adenoviral infection that is spread commonly among groups of people. EKC usually manifests with bilateral ocular pain, foreign body sensation, blurring of vision, conjunctival injection, and edema of the eyelids and conjunctiva. While corneal involvement with subepithelial infiltrates may develop after a few days, EKC affects both eyes and does not manifest with rapid onset of a circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon.

C) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa easily adheres to contact lenses and is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among contact lens users. Risk factors include wearing contact lenses for an extended period of time and poor contact lens hygiene. Pseudomonas keratitis typically manifests with a rapid progression of symptoms, such as a decline in vision, eye pain, redness, photophobia, and foreign body sensation. If left untreated, pseudomonas keratitis can lead to corneal perforation within 2–5 days. Therefore, urgent treatment with topical broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., cefazolin with tobramycin or gentamicin) should be initiated. In addition, patients should be educated about contact lens hygiene (washing hands before touching the lenses, using fresh lens solution, not using saliva to wet lenses).

Key learning point: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of rapidly progressive bacterial keratitis in contact lens users, requiring urgent treatment to prevent corneal perforation.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex keratitis (HSV keratitis) can manifest with ocular pain and blurry vision. However, HSV keratitis typically progresses over 1–3 days; unlike this patient's rapid development in one day. In addition, slit lamp examination in HSV keratitis would show the pathognomonic dendritic ulcer rather than the circular corneal infiltrate and hypopyon seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus keratitis is the most common cause of bacterial keratitis among individuals who do not use contact lenses, and it can manifest with a painful decline in vision, conjunctival injection, hypopyon, and corneal infiltrates. However, this patient's history of contact lens use and the rapid progression of symptoms make another causative organism more likely.
questions.hint: The photograph shows conjunctival injection, accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber (hypopyon), and a round corneal infiltrate suggestive of an ulcer. In a patient using contact lenses, these findings indicate infective keratitis caused by a specific pathogen.

questions.text: A 32-year-old presents with 2 days of unilateral eye pain, photophobia, and decreased vision. The patient denies any recent trauma or contact lens use. Examination shows conjunctival injection and watery discharge. Visual acuity is 20/100. Fluorescein staining on slit-lamp examination is shown. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical ciprofloxacin is used for bacterial keratitis, which typically presents with purulent discharge, hypopyon, and round corneal infiltrates or ulcers. This patient's presentation with the characteristic dendritic ulcer pattern visible on fluorescein staining indicates viral rather than bacterial etiology.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has herpes simplex keratitis based on the characteristic dendritic ulcers visible on fluorescein staining that resemble tree branches. HSV keratitis results from reactivated herpes simplex virus type 1 from the trigeminal ganglion and typically presents with unilateral eye pain and photophobia. Topical trifluridine is the appropriate first-line treatment for epithelial HSV keratitis. Oral acyclovir can be used for HSV keratitis when topical treatment cannot be administered by the patient, for prophylactic treatment after surgery, or for refractory cases despite topical treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is first-line therapy for herpes zoster keratitis, which presents with punctate rather than dendritic corneal lesions and is associated with characteristic vesicular eruption on the forehead, bridge, and tip of the nose in the ophthalmic nerve distribution. The dendritic pattern seen here is pathognomonic for herpes simplex virus (HSV) rather than zoster. Oral acyclovir can be used for HSV keratitis when topical treatment cannot be administered by the patient, for prophylactic treatment after surgery, or for refractory cases despite topical treatment. For initial epithelial HSV keratitis, like in this patient, topical therapy is preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

Supportive care with artificial tears would be appropriate for mild corneal abrasions or dry eye syndrome. This patient has a significant corneal epithelial defect in a dendritic pattern that requires specific antiviral treatment to prevent progression and complications.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical prednisolone is used for anterior uveitis, which presents with photophobia and eye pain but typically shows cells and flare in the anterior chamber rather than corneal epithelial defects. Corticosteroids are contraindicated in the initial treatment of infectious keratitis as they can worsen the infection and lead to corneal perforation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old contact lens wearer presents overnight to the emergency department with severe unilateral eye pain, photophobia, and purulent discharge that began yesterday. Visual acuity is 20/100. Slit-lamp examination is shown. The rest of the head and neck examination is normal. Ophthalmology has been contacted but is currently operating on another patient with ocular trauma. What is the most appropriate interim management?

choices.text: Perform therapeutic mydriasis with supportive care

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – The combination of contact lens use, purulent discharge, acute 2-day onset, and slit-lamp findings is consistent with bacterial keratitis. The image demonstrates the characteristic corneal infiltrate with a hypopyon (layered inflammatory cells in the anterior chamber). This is an ophthalmic emergency requiring immediate topical broad-spectrum antibiotics such as ofloxacin or ciprofloxacin. Treatment should be initiated within 24 hours to prevent ulceration and corneal destruction, particularly with Pseudomonas species common in contact lens users, which can cause perforation within 2-5 days.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids and cycloplegics are appropriate treatments for inflammatory uveitis. While the hypopyon seen in this patient can occur in noninfectious anterior uveitis, the purulent discharge in this contact lens wearer suggests an infectious etiology rather than sterile inflammation. Additionally, the acute 2-day onset is more consistent with bacterial infection than typical uveitis patterns. Initiating corticosteroids before controlling infection could accelerate corneal destruction.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's examination shows a hazy corneal infiltrate and hypopyon, which could occur with bacterial, viral, or fungal keratitis. While herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can cause hypopyon in rare, severe cases, it typically produces a watery discharge. This clinical presentation in a contact lens wearer with purulent discharge is more consistent with bacterial infection. Slit-lamp examination with fluorescein can help identify or rule out characteristic dendritic lesions of HSV keratitis if the diagnosis is uncertain. Herpes zoster keratitis, which is treated with oral antivirals, typically presents with punctate lesions on fluorescein staining as well as characteristic lesions on the face, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Topic chlorhexidine is an appropriate treatment for Acanthamoeba keratitis. While Acanthamoeba infection does occur in contact lens users and can be severe, it typically has a more indolent course, developing over weeks rather than the acute presentation of this patient. The purulent discharge is also less characteristic of Acanthamoeba infection. Chlorhexidine treatment would be inappropriate for the most likely infectious cause in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although therapeutic mydriasis can provide symptomatic relief and help prevent synechiae when inflammatory cells are present in the anterior chamber, it does not address the underlying infectious process suggested by the contact lens use and purulent discharge. Supportive care alone would allow progression of the underlying condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old welder presents to the emergency department with bilateral eye pain, photophobia, and foreign body sensation that began 8 hours after welding without protective eyewear. Slit-lamp examination shows bilateral fine-spotted superficial corneal epithelial lesions with fluorescein uptake. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

choices.text: Topical antiviral therapy with trifluridine solution
Antibiotic eye ointment and oral analgesics
Large-volume saline irrigation and pH measurement
Foreign body removal with corneal spud and tetanus prophylaxis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical broad-spectrum antibiotics like ciprofloxacin would be appropriate for bacterial keratitis, which typically presents with progressive pain, purulent discharge, and may show hypopyon or round corneal infiltrates. However, this patient's bilateral presentation with fine-spotted lesions following UV exposure is consistent with photokeratitis rather than bacterial infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antiviral therapy with trifluridine would be indicated for herpes simplex keratitis, which characteristically presents with dendritic ulcers on fluorescein staining and is typically unilateral. This patient's bilateral fine-spotted lesions and clear UV exposure history make photokeratitis more likely than viral keratitis.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has photokeratitis from welding without protective eyewear, as evidenced by the bilateral fine-spotted superficial epithelial lesions appearing 8 hours after UV exposure. Treatment includes antibiotic eye ointment to prevent secondary infection and oral analgesics for pain management.

D) INCORRECT:

Large-volume saline irrigation and pH measurement would be the immediate treatment for ocular chemical burns, which present with intense pain, erythematous or whitened conjunctiva, and cloudy cornea. This patient's bilateral fine-spotted epithelial lesions following welding exposure indicate photokeratitis rather than chemical exposure.

E) INCORRECT:

Foreign body removal with corneal spud and tetanus prophylaxis would be appropriate for corneal foreign bodies, which typically present with sudden onset discomfort, visible foreign bodies, or rust rings on examination. This patient's bilateral fine-spotted lesions without visible foreign bodies indicate photokeratitis rather than retained foreign material.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of severe right eye pain, photophobia, and blurred vision. She frequently sleeps in her soft contact lenses. Physical examination shows marked conjunctival injection and a hazy opacity on the central cornea. Fluorescein staining shows a corneal epithelial defect with an underlying infiltrate. This patient's condition is most likely caused by which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis causes adult inclusion conjunctivitis, which typically manifests as a chronic follicular conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge. While it can cause a peripheral keratitis, it does not cause an acute, severe central corneal ulcer as described in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of bacterial keratitis overall. However, it is more typically a cause of keratitis in patients with ocular surface disease, such as blepharitis or dry eye, or after corneal trauma. While possible, it is not the most likely pathogen in a patient who sleeps in contact lenses.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a common cause of infectious keratitis, but the infection does not typically result from contact lens wear. The classic finding of HSV epithelial keratitis on fluorescein staining is a dendritic, or branching, ulcer. This patient's examination findings of a hazy opacity and infiltrate without a dendritic pattern make this diagnosis less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a gram-negative rod, is the most common and virulent pathogen in contact lens-associated bacterial keratitis. The warm, moist, low-oxygen environment created by an overworn contact lens allows the organism to proliferate and produce enzymes that can rapidly destroy the cornea. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with intensive topical antibiotics, often fortified tobramycin or a fluoroquinolone, are crucial to prevent permanent vision loss from corneal scarring or perforation.

E) INCORRECT:

Acanthamoeba keratitis is a consideration in contact lens wearers, but it is much rarer than bacterial keratitis. It typically occurs after exposure to contaminated water, such as from swimming pools, hot tubs, or tap water used for lens cleaning. The pain is often described as severe and out of proportion to the clinical signs, and a ring-shaped infiltrate is a classic but often late finding.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of infectious keratitis (i.e., a corneal ulcer), which is an ophthalmologic emergency. The most important risk factor is sleeping in contact lenses.
